tasks.title: Environment Setup & ROS2 Foxy Optimization
tasks.description: Verify and optimize the existing Ubuntu 20.04.5 LTS, ROS2 Foxy, Python 3.8.10, and CUDA 11.4 environment on the NVIDIA Jetson Orin NX. Configure the `cyclonedx_ws` workspace for Unitree's CycloneDDS-based communication as per official guidelines. Build upon the completed Claudia project structure to integrate ROS2 environment with the established Python package architecture.
tasks.details: Ensure Ubuntu 20.04.5 LTS (aarch64, Tegra R35.3.1) is stable. Verify ROS2 Foxy installation and its compatibility with Ubuntu 20.04. Confirm Python 3.8.10 and CUDA 11.4 toolkit are correctly installed and operational. Set up the `cyclonedx_ws` by cloning `unitree_ros2` and `unitree_sdk2` if necessary, focusing on compiling Unitree ROS2 msg definitions. Integrate the ROS2 workspace with the existing Claudia project structure (src/claudia/) that has been successfully created with modular organization including ai_components, robot_controller, sensors, vision, navigation, audio, and common modules. This aligns with the 'âœ… å®˜æ–¹éªŒè¯é…ç½®'.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify OS version (`uname -a`, tegra version). Check `ros2 doctor`. Run `python --version` and `nvcc --version`. Successfully compile `cyclonedx_ws` and list available Unitree ROS2 topics/services. Test basic DDS communication using ROS2 tools. Verify integration between ROS2 environment and Claudia project structure by testing imports and configuration loading.

tasks.title: Install Core Unitree SDKs (`unitree_sdk2`, `unitree_ros2`)
tasks.description: Install the core Unitree SDKs: `unitree_sdk2` (CycloneDDS based) and `unitree_ros2` (ROS2 integration package). This task has been completed successfully with comprehensive installation and verification of all SDK components.
tasks.details: Successfully installed and verified complete Unitree SDK ecosystem including: 4 Unitree ROS2 packages (unitree_api, unitree_go, unitree_hg, unitree_ros2_example), 43 message interfaces (including critical LowCmd, LowState, SportModeState, Request, Response), 33 SDK library files (C++ compilation libraries and bindings), and full ROS2 integration. Created comprehensive installation tools including setup script (scripts/setup/install_unitree_sdks.sh), environment configuration (.env.unitree_sdk), and detailed installation report (unitree_sdk_installation_report.md). All system dependencies, repository integrity, compilation verification, interface testing, communication testing, and Python integration have been validated successfully.
tasks.testStrategy: All tests completed successfully: CycloneDX workspace compilation verified, all 43 Unitree message interfaces accessible via ROS2 (`ros2 msg list | grep unitree`), DDS communication functioning properly, Python message package imports working, and comprehensive 489-line verification script validates entire installation. System is ready for unitree_sdk2py Python interface installation and robot communication testing.

tasks.title: Install `unitree_sdk2py` & Basic Robot Communication Test
tasks.description: Successfully installed the `unitree_sdk2py` Python interface after resolving critical cyclonedx naming issues. The installation is now complete with all dependencies properly configured. Focus has shifted to executing comprehensive communication tests with the Unitree Go2 robot and validating the Python interface functionality.
tasks.details: Major breakthrough achieved: Successfully resolved the cyclonedx/cyclonedds naming error and completed full installation. Key accomplishments: (1) Corrected package name from 'cyclonedx' to 'cyclonedx', (2) Used correct GitHub repository eclipse-cyclonedx/cyclonedx, (3) Successfully compiled and installed cyclonedx 0.10.x core libraries and headers, (4) Installed unitree_sdk2py with all dependencies (opencv-python, rich, rich-click), (5) Created test_unitree_connection.py script with state subscription, timeout handling, and error diagnostics. Next phase focuses on executing communication tests, validating robot state reading, and testing basic control commands (STANDUP/STANDDOWN) using the Sport API.
tasks.testStrategy: Execute the created test_unitree_connection.py script to verify robot communication. Successfully read and display robot state data including IMU information. Test basic control commands (STANDUP 1004, STANDDOWN 1005) and observe physical robot responses. Validate communication latency is <50ms for control commands. Verify error handling and timeout mechanisms work correctly.

tasks.title: Hardware & Sensor System Validation (LiDAR, Camera, IMU, Audio)
tasks.description: Systematically validate the functionality of all key hardware components and sensors on the Unitree Go2 R&D Plus via the `unitree_sdk2py` interface. This includes the 4D LiDAR L1, front camera, IMU, foot-end force sensors, and audio I/O.
tasks.details: Develop Python scripts using `unitree_sdk2py` to: 1. Access and print data streams from Unitree 4D LiDAR L1 (e.g., point cloud snippets, rotation speed). 2. Capture and display images from the front HD camera (1280x720). 3. Read and log data from the built-in IMU (accelerometer, gyroscope). 4. Read and display values from the foot-end force sensors (R&D Plus specific). 5. Test audio input from the microphone array (record a short clip) and audio output to the built-in speaker (play a test sound). Refer to `/usr/local/include/unitree/go2_idl/` for data structures like `LidarState_.hpp`, `IMUState_.hpp`, `AudioData_.hpp`.
tasks.testStrategy: Confirm data reception from each sensor. LiDAR: visualize point cloud or check data rate (21600 points/s). Camera: view live feed. IMU: check for changing values during motion. Force sensors: observe value changes when pressing on feet. Audio: successfully record and playback audio. All tests via Python scripts.

tasks.title: Intel RealSense D435i Integration & Data Acquisition
tasks.description: Integrate the Intel RealSense D435i depth camera. Verify the `ros-foxy-realsense2-camera (v4.51.1)` package installation and ensure RGB, depth, and infrared data streams are accessible within the ROS2 Foxy environment.
tasks.details: Confirm `ros-foxy-realsense2-camera` (version 4.51.1) is installed and configured. Launch the RealSense ROS2 node (`ros2 launch realsense2_camera rs_launch.py`). Verify that topics for RGB images (e.g., `/camera/color/image_raw`), depth images (e.g., `/camera/depth/image_rect_raw`), aligned depth images (e.g., `/camera/aligned_depth_to_color/image_raw`), and point clouds (e.g., `/camera/depth/color/points`) are published. Ensure camera serial number 346522073864 is recognized. Prioritize 4D LiDAR L1, but ensure D435i is ready as an enhancement.
tasks.testStrategy: Successfully launch RealSense node. Use `ros2 topic echo` or `rviz2` to visualize RGB, depth, and point cloud data from D435i. Verify depth resolution (e.g., 1280x720@30fps) and minimum depth distance (0.105m). Confirm all 6 video devices are available if applicable.

tasks.title: LED Control System Implementation (Compatible & Adaptive)
tasks.description: Develop a Python module to control the Go2's front LED array using the `unitree_go::msg::LowCmd` message, specifically the `uint8[12] led` field. Implement Cluadia-specific LED status indicators ensuring compatibility with system default LED states and include environment light adaptation.
tasks.details: Create a Python class/module that interfaces with `unitree_sdk2py` to send `LowCmd` messages. Map Cluadia states to specific LED patterns: Green double flash (å”¤é†’ç¡®è®¤), Blue solid (å¤„ç†è¯­éŸ³), Orange solid (æ‰§è¡ŒåŠ¨ä½œ), White short 3 flashes (åŠ¨ä½œå®Œæˆ), Red triple flash (é”™è¯¯/æ— æ³•ç†è§£). These must be distinct from system defaults (Green solid:å¼€æœº, Blue flashing:æ ¡å‡†, Yellow flashing:ä½ç”µ, White solid:æœç´¢ç¯). Implement logic to read ambient light from the front camera (or a dedicated sensor if available) and adjust LED brightness accordingly. Reference: `led_` field in `/usr/local/include/unitree/go2_idl/LowCmd_.hpp`.
tasks.testStrategy: Visually verify each Cluadia-specific LED pattern can be triggered via Python script. Confirm that system default LED states are not overridden or interfered with. Test LED brightness adjustment in varying light conditions. LED state switching latency < 200ms.

tasks.title: Wake Word Detection System (PicoVoice Porcupine for Japanese)
tasks.description: Integrate the PicoVoice Porcupine wake word detection engine. Train and deploy custom Japanese wake word models for "ã­ãˆã€ãã‚‰" (primary) and "ãã‚‰ã“ã„" (secondary). Implement a low-power continuous listening loop.
tasks.details: Install PicoVoice Porcupine Python SDK. Use the Picovoice Console to create `.ppn` model files for the Japanese wake words "ã­ãˆã€ãã‚‰" and "ãã‚‰ã“ã„". Write a Python script that uses the Go2's microphone array (via `unitree_sdk2py` or system audio) as input for Porcupine. Implement a loop that continuously processes audio chunks and triggers an event upon wake word detection. Ensure low CPU usage (<10% on one core) and memory footprint (<5MB).
tasks.testStrategy: Test wake word detection accuracy for "ã­ãˆã€ãã‚‰" and "ãã‚‰ã“ã„" in quiet and noisy environments. Measure detection latency (<100ms). Monitor CPU and memory usage during continuous listening. Verify robustness against false positives.

tasks.title: Japanese ASR System (NVIDIA Parakeet-TDT CTC 0.6B)
tasks.description: Deploy the NVIDIA Parakeet-TDT CTC 0.6B Japanese ASR model (`nvidia/parakeet-tdt_ctc-0.6b-ja`) on the Jetson Orin NX. Optimize its performance using NVIDIA TensorRT and integrate it with the audio input stream from Go2's microphone array.
tasks.details: Download the Parakeet-TDT CTC 0.6B Japanese model. Convert and optimize it for TensorRT on the Jetson Orin NX. Develop a Python service that takes an audio stream (post-wake word detection) from Go2's microphone array, performs ASR, and outputs the recognized Japanese text. Implement audio pre-processing suitable for the model and microphone characteristics. Aim for low latency.
tasks.testStrategy: Test ASR accuracy with various Japanese spoken commands relevant to the PRD. Measure end-to-end ASR latency (target < 500ms). Evaluate performance in noisy environments. Target ASR accuracy >90% in quiet, >80% in noisy environments.

tasks.title: Japanese TTS System (`esnya/japanese_speecht5_tts`)
tasks.description: Deploy the `esnya/japanese_speecht5_tts` text-to-speech model on the Jetson Orin NX for Japanese voice synthesis. Integrate with a HiFiGAN vocoder for quality audio output through Go2's built-in speaker. Allow dynamic enabling/disabling of TTS output.
tasks.details: Set up the `japanese_speecht5_tts` model (144M parameters) and a compatible HiFiGAN vocoder. Use `SpeechT5FeatureExtractor` and `SpeechT5Processor`. Implement logic for multi-sentence processing to handle pauses correctly. Configure 16-dim speaker embeddings for voice personalization (e.g., male/female). Create a Python service that accepts Japanese text and generates speech audio, outputting through Go2's speaker. Implement a runtime switch to enable/disable TTS.
tasks.testStrategy: Test TTS naturalness (target MOS > 4.0/5.0) and intelligibility for various Japanese sentences. Measure synthesis latency (target < 200ms for short phrases). Verify dynamic enable/disable of audio output. Test different speaker embeddings.

tasks.title: LLM Deployment (Qwen2.5-7B INT4 Quantized)
tasks.description: Deploy the Qwen2.5-7B Large Language Model, INT4 quantized, on the NVIDIA Jetson Orin NX. Develop an API for processing Japanese text input to understand intent and extract relevant parameters for robot actions.
tasks.details: Obtain the Qwen2.5-7B model and quantize it to INT4 precision suitable for Jetson Orin NX (15GB RAM). Use a framework like llama.cpp, TensorRT-LLM, or vLLM if supported and optimized for Orin NX. Create a Python service that exposes an API (e.g., HTTP or ROS2 service) to take Japanese text from ASR, process it with Qwen2.5, and return structured output (intent, entities, parameters). Optimize prompt engineering for Japanese commands related to Go2 actions.
tasks.testStrategy: Test LLM's ability to correctly interpret various Japanese commands (simple, complex, colloquial). Measure inference latency (target 1.5-2.5s for typical commands). Verify accuracy of intent recognition and parameter extraction. Monitor RAM usage during inference.

tasks.title: Preset Action Mapping & Execution (LLM to `unitree_sdk2py`)
tasks.description: Create a mapping system from natural Japanese commands (interpreted by the LLM) to specific Unitree Go2 Sport API calls via `unitree_sdk2py`. Implement the logic for the LLM's output to trigger these pre-defined actions.
tasks.details: Analyze the 27 available Go2 Sport API actions (from `sport_api.hpp`, e.g., `HELLO(1016)`, `SIT(1009)`, `STRETCH(1017)`, `DANCE1(1022)`). Develop a Python module that takes the structured output from the LLM (Task 10) and translates it into calls to the corresponding `unitree_sdk2py` functions. For example, if LLM identifies intent 'greet', map to `HELLO(1016)`. For 'è½¬åœˆ (turn circle)', combine `EULER(1007)` and `MOVE(1008)` or use a dance API if suitable. This replaces remote control triggers.
tasks.testStrategy: Test with various Japanese commands: "ãŠæ‰‹" -> HELLO, "ãŠåº§ã‚Š" -> SIT, "ä¼¸å±•" -> STRETCH, "ãƒ€ãƒ³ã‚¹" -> DANCE1/2. Verify correct action execution on the robot. Ensure LLM output is correctly parsed and mapped. Test composite actions like 'è½¬åœˆ'.

tasks.title: Stage 1 End-to-End Voice Interaction & 'ãã‚‰ã“ã„' Response
tasks.description: Integrate all Stage 1 components: wake word, ASR, LLM, preset action execution, TTS, and LED feedback into a cohesive voice interaction flow. Implement the special "ãã‚‰ã“ã„" / "ãã‚‰ãŠã„ã§" direct call response and continuous dialogue mode.
tasks.details: Orchestrate the full sequence: 1. Porcupine detects "ã­ãˆã€ãã‚‰". 2. LED: Green double flash. 3. ASR processes subsequent user speech. 4. LED: Blue solid. 5. LLM interprets command. 6. Action mapped and executed via `unitree_sdk2py`. 7. LED: Orange solid during action. 8. TTS provides verbal feedback (if enabled). 9. LED: White 3 flashes on completion. For "ãã‚‰ã“ã„"/"ãã‚‰ãŠã„ã§": bypass wake word, perform sound localization (if possible, or default approach), approach user, execute friendly gesture. Implement continuous dialogue: after an action, wait ~10s for follow-up commands without re-wake. Timeout returns to listening.
tasks.testStrategy: End-to-end test of the full interaction loop with various commands. Verify correct LED state transitions. Test "ãã‚‰ã“ã„" response. Test continuous dialogue mode and timeout. Measure overall response latency (target <3s for simple commands, <4s for complex).

tasks.title: YOLOv8s Object Detection System (Dual Camera Strategy)
tasks.description: Deploy YOLOv8s object detection (TensorRT optimized) on Jetson Orin NX. Implement the dual-camera strategy: Go2 main camera (1280x720@120Â°) for primary wide-angle detection, and Intel RealSense D435i for depth-enhanced 3D localization and as a high-resolution backup RGB detector. Customize for relevant environmental objects.
tasks.details: Use YOLOv8s model, optimized with TensorRT for Orin NX. Primary detection pipeline: Go2 main camera -> YOLOv8s -> 2D bounding boxes. Secondary/Enhancement: RealSense D435i RGB stream for backup detection (if main fails or for higher res details) and its depth stream to project 2D detections from either camera into 3D space. Implement fusion logic for detections from both sources if active concurrently, and a failover mechanism. Customize COCO classes or retrain for objects like 'person', 'desk', 'chair', 'bookshelf', 'door', 'signage'. Allocate GPU resources (e.g., 25% for main YOLO, 15% for backup if active).
tasks.testStrategy: Test object detection accuracy (mAP) and speed (FPS, target 60 FPS for main camera, 40 FPS for RealSense backup) for customized classes. Verify 3D localization accuracy of detected objects (<0.15m error). Test camera failover and fusion logic. Ensure GPU usage is within allocated budget.

tasks.title: LLM-driven Dynamic Action Sequence Generation (Stage 2)
tasks.description: Extend LLM capabilities to parse complex, sequential commands (e.g., "å…ˆåä¸‹ç„¶åè½¬åœˆæœ€åæ¡æ‰‹" - "first sit, then turn, then handshake") and generate an ordered sequence of basic actions or dynamically create ROS action nodes for execution.
tasks.details: Refine LLM prompting and parsing logic to understand multi-step instructions. The LLM should output a structured plan, e.g., a list of recognized basic actions with their parameters in the correct order. For more complex or novel combinations, the LLM could potentially generate specifications for new ROS action nodes/sequences, though initially focus on sequencing known Sport API actions. This involves more sophisticated state management and execution control than single preset actions.
tasks.testStrategy: Test with various complex sequential commands. Verify the LLM correctly decomposes the command into a sequence of known actions. Observe the robot executing the sequence correctly. Evaluate robustness to variations in phrasing complex commands.

tasks.title: Multi-modal Sensor Fusion Framework
tasks.description: Develop a framework for fusing data from multiple modalities: 4D LiDAR L1 (point clouds), Go2 front camera (visual features, YOLO detections), RealSense D435i (RGB-D, YOLO detections), IMU (motion data), and foot-end force sensors (contact data).
tasks.details: Design a ROS2-based data fusion pipeline. Implement time synchronization for sensor data streams. Fuse LiDAR geometric features with YOLO-derived semantic features from camera images. Incorporate depth information from RealSense for 3D scene understanding. Use IMU data for motion compensation and state estimation. Integrate foot-end force sensor data for terrain assessment or contact detection. The output should be a richer, more robust representation of the environment and robot state.
tasks.testStrategy: Visualize fused data in RViz2 (e.g., point clouds colored by semantic labels from YOLO). Verify improved environmental representation compared to single sensor modalities. Test robustness of fusion to individual sensor noise or temporary outages.

tasks.title: Unsupervised SLAM & Environment Mapping (YOLO-enhanced)
tasks.description: Implement an unsupervised SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) system. Utilize fused multi-modal sensor data, particularly LiDAR point clouds enhanced by YOLO-detected objects as semantic landmarks, for robust self-organizing map construction and topological structure discovery.
tasks.details: Choose or develop an unsupervised SLAM algorithm suitable for ROS2 and the available sensors (e.g., graph-based SLAM). Input: fused data from Task 15. Key aspects: use YOLO-detected stable objects (e.g., 'door', 'desk') as semantic landmarks to improve loop closure detection and map consistency. Focus on building a 2D or 2.5D map initially. The system should autonomously discover the environment's topological connections.
tasks.testStrategy: Deploy the robot in a test environment. Evaluate map accuracy and consistency generated by SLAM. Verify correct identification and use of semantic landmarks. Test loop closure performance. Assess localization accuracy within the generated map (target <0.5m error).

tasks.title: Unsupervised Semantic Navigation & Path Planning (YOLO-enhanced)
tasks.description: Develop an unsupervised semantic navigation system. The system should learn to associate natural language commands (e.g., "take me to the library") with spatial locations on the SLAM map, using YOLO-detected object contexts for semantic understanding. Implement curiosity-driven exploration and reinforcement learning for path planning and obstacle avoidance.
tasks.details: Integrate LLM for understanding navigation commands. The system needs to: 1. Learn semantic labels for areas on the map (e.g., area with 'bookshelves' and 'desks' is 'library') based on YOLO detections and user interaction/guidance. 2. Implement a path planner (e.g., A*, D*) operating on the SLAM map. 3. Use reinforcement learning (RL) or an information gain approach (curiosity-driven) for exploration of unknown areas. 4. Implement dynamic obstacle avoidance using LiDAR and camera data. The navigation should be goal-oriented based on semantic understanding.
tasks.testStrategy: Test navigation to semantically defined goals (e.g., "go to the area with the sofa"). Evaluate path planning efficiency and obstacle avoidance capabilities. Assess exploration strategy in new environments. Verify learning of new semantic locations. Navigation accuracy target <0.5m position error.

tasks.title: System Performance Optimization, Stability & Thermal Management
tasks.description: Conduct comprehensive system-wide performance optimization, stability testing, and thermal management validation. This includes response latencies, accuracies, resource utilization, fault recovery, and long-duration operational stability.
tasks.details: Profile CPU, GPU, and memory usage of all components. Optimize critical paths to meet performance targets (e.g., voice response <3s, YOLO >60FPS). Implement thermal monitoring for Jetson Orin NX (CPU/GPU temps). If overheating occurs (GPU >85Â°C, CPU >80Â°C), implement performance throttling or activate cooling fans if available. Test system stability over extended periods (target >1.5 hours continuous operation with all features active). Test fault recovery mechanisms (e.g., process crashes, sensor disconnects). Validate all performance metrics from PRD.
tasks.testStrategy: Run predefined test scenarios covering all functionalities. Log performance metrics, resource usage, and temperatures. Conduct stress tests and long-duration tests. Simulate faults to verify recovery. Compare results against PRD performance targets.
